awd_titl_txt: CPS: TTP Option: Medium: Identifying, Characterizing, and Shaping Multi-Scale Cyber-Human Interactions in Mixed Autonomous/Conventional Vehicle Traffic
awd_abstract_narration:
The promise of intelligent transportation systems is safety, mobility, and efficiencies well beyond current technologies. Yet, transportation engineers and planners must anticipate future transportation needs for which the enabling technologies are rapidly evolving while the change-over from old to new transportation technologies will take decades.  This project seeks to understand the impact of these trends for transportation engineering, offer approaches for effective shared control between autonomous vehicles and drivers, and provide insight into strategies to realize the promise of intelligent transportation systems.  The approach to studying traffic uses driving simulators, built on a high-performance computing architecture, that enables high-resolution, physics-based, realistic, interactive simulations, necessary for detailed modeling of vehicles and drivers under changing traffic conditions and various assumptions on autonomy, control, and connectedness, and for monitoring human driving behaviors.

This project identifies, characterizes, and shapes human cyber-physical interactions, bound to emerge in future mixed autonomous and conventional vehicle traffic. Its aims are to: (1) better understand human-cyber-physical interactions in mixed traffic, particularly driver trust in vehicle automation; (2) develop analytical and computational methods to assess the impacts on traffic capacity and regime transition for scenarios in which a driver switches from autonomous vehicle mode to conventional vehicle mode (e.g., loss of trust in automation scenarios); and (3) develop engineering solutions to enhance cyber-human interactions and traffic flow. The research embraces a multi-scale analysis approach anchored in human behavior analysis and interface design, modeling of mixed traffic and vehicle control, and system-level analysis of interdependency among human, vehicles, and traffic.  Understanding of human cyber-physical interactions through this project will enable better future designs of autonomous vehicles and the ways in which humans interact with these evolving systems safely and dependably.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
Summary of Research Outcomes

Autonomous vehicles (AVs) promise safer and more efficient roads by removing human error from driving. However, as we transition into a world where AVs and traditional vehicles share the road, human drivers still play a critical role---especially when they need to decide whether to rely on or override automation. These decisions impact traffic flow and safety, particularly in mixed traffic environments with varying levels of automation.

This research set out to understand when and why drivers intervene with partially automated systems and how those interventions affect traffic stability. The team developed computational models to predict driver intervention and assessed their effect on traffic flow. Based on these insights, researchers also created driver interfaces and control strategies aimed at reducing unnecessary interventions, improving safety and efficiency.

To conduct this work, the team built a high-fidelity simulation platform, SynChrono, which realistically models both human-driven and autonomous vehicles. This was integrated with a driving simulator, creating Chrono-R, a unique environment for studying human interactions with AVs (Figure 1). Experiments using this platform allowed researchers to gather data on driver decisions and transitions between manual and automated control (Figure 2). The dynamic decision-making process of interventions was modeled using this data in an evidence accumulation modeling framework (Figure 3).

Key findings showed that unnecessary driver interventions can cause traffic disturbances that ripple through the system (Figure 4). To address this, the team developed a reinforcement learning-based control strategy that reduced these disturbances and improved traffic stability by up to 30% in simulation tests (Figure 5). Additionally, experiments showed that assigning drivers non-driving tasks during automated driving could reduce unnecessary interventions, supporting smarter interface design.

Intellectual Merit

This project advanced the state of knowledge regarding how individuals interact with autonomous systems. Traditional models of driver behavior focus on reaction times and control inputs, but this work went further---modeling psychological factors like trust in automation and the propensity to intervene. These models are essential for maximizing the benefits of AVs, which depend on people's willingness to use and trust the technology. New traffic flow models for mixed AV systems were also developed, offering insight into how human behavior influences system-level performance. The research emphasized that even with advanced automation, human decision-making remains a key factor in traffic efficiency and safety.

Broader Impacts

While the focus was on driving, the findings apply to any situation where humans can choose to override automation---such as AI assistants in offices or automated systems in military operations. The idea that human-automation interactions can produce system-wide consequences is an important lesson for many domains.

The research also produced Chrono::HIL, a novel software platform that allows a human driver in a simulator to interact with multiple autonomous vehicles in real-time. Demonstrated using a San Francisco neighborhood simulation, the software is open-source, its development is continuing, and it is currently being integrated with the National Advanced Driving Simulator (NADS) (Figure 6). The integration of SynChrono with the driving simulator broadened the types of driving scenarios that can now be studied---particularly those where human behavior and automation interact under dynamic conditions. This capability supports more realistic testing and development of AV technology by other researchers and industries.

The project supported 3 postdoctoral researchers, 6 Ph.D. students, 4 master's students, and 3 undergraduate students. Research findings were integrated into both undergraduate and graduate courses. Students experienced driving simulators, conducted their own AV studies, and explored what it is like to drive around AVs versus human-driven cars. High school students and other visitors were introduced to this research through lab tours and demos. A new course, Computer Modeling and Simulation of Autonomous Vehicles and Robots, was also created. Aimed at senior undergraduates and early graduate students, the course teaches students how to simulate AVs and robots using physics-based models, virtual environments, sensor data, and autonomy algorithms. The course culminates in students designing and testing their own simulated AVs---an innovative and unique educational experience in the U.S.

The integration of Chrono with the driving simulator broadened the types of driving scenarios that can now be studied---particularly those where human behavior and automation interact under dynamic conditions. This capability supports more realistic testing and development of AV technology.

This work has the potential to improve the everyday driving experience and reduce traffic congestion by designing systems that support smarter driver behavior and better interaction between human-driven and autonomous vehicles. By decreasing unnecessary interventions and the resulting traffic disturbances, AVs can fulfill their promise of safer and more efficient roads. The project's findings have been shared widely, including a contribution to the FHWA titled "Preparing Our Nation’s Roadways for Advanced Vehicle Technologies."


Last Modified: 04/09/2025
Modified by: Soyoung Ahn
